Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolutionary Genomics of piRNA-Mediated Transposon Silencing in Drosophila
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to understand how ongoing conflict between selfish DNA ?parasites? and control by their host may result in reproductive isolation between species. Transposable elements (TEs) are short fragments of DNA that have the ability to insert, and perpetuate themselves, throughout a host genome. TE insertions can be deleterious for the host when they disrupt the function of the host genes. Small-RNA molecules called piRNAs have recently been shown to be an important way for the host to control the proliferation of TEs during the formation of egg and sperm cells. This research will characterize the rate of joint evolution of piRNAs and TEs in three closely-related species species of fruit flies. The project aims to: (1) determine the sequence of piRNAs in these species, (2) measure TE diversity, and (3) identify the rapidly evolving proteins that are known to be important for the piRNA suppression system.

Several human genetic diseases, including cancer are associated with TE mobilization. Understanding the evolution of piRNA-mediated TE defense may aid in the effective treatment for human genetic diseases. Additionally, this research will provide training opportunities for undergraduate and high school students in the emerging areas of genomics and bioinformatics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Jeffrey Vedanayagam has completed his dissertation research "Evolutionary genomics of piRNA-mediated transposon silencing in Drosophila" funded by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. His dissertation work was supervised by Prof. Daniel Garrigan at the University of Rochester. As an evolutionary biologist, Vedanayagam was interested in studying the evolution of transposable elements (TEs) in the fruit fly. TEs are selfish genetic elements that are found in most living organisms. TE multiplication threatens host fitness as these DNA parasites can disrupt the normal function of protein-coding genes. Vedanayagam, in his dissertation work studied the evolution of a host defense mechanism that controls TE multiplication in four closely related Drosophila species.

The host defense machinery that controls TE multiplication generates small RNA molecules called piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs), which targets and destroys active TEs. Interestingly, piRNAs are generated from inactive TE-rich regions in the genome called "piRNA clusters", which target active TEs for silencing. In this study, Vedanayagam and Garrigan performed a comparative genomic analysis of piRNA-mediated TE silencing in D. melanogaster and three species of the D. simulans clade. They generated two high quality next-generation sequence data sets. The first data set is the sequence of small RNAs from these Drosophila species. Using these small RNAs as a proxy, Vedanayagam and Garrigan determined the TE diversity in these closely related species. Furthermore, they find that there is a rapid turnover of TE sequences in these closely related species, which indicate evasion of host silencing by TEs.

Next, Vedanayagam and Garrigan studied the evolution of the host proteins that controls TE activity. Collectively termed as piRNA pathway, a comprehensive molecular evolutionary analysis of these proteins in three  Drosophila species shows that the host silencing machinery is among top 5% rapidly evolving genes in Drosophila. Both dynamic turnover of TEs in closely related species, and rapid evolution of the piRNA pathway suggests antagonistic co-evolution between TEs and the host silencing machinery.

Additionally, Vedanayagam and Garrigan collected another next-generation sequence data set, where they generated long-range single molecule sequence data to determine the sequence composition of  TE rich piRNA clusters in these Drosophila species. This data set enabled the characterization of a master piRNA generating locus called flamenco in D. mauritiana, which harbors several novel TE insertions compared to the model organism D. melanogaster, suggesting rapid turnover of piRNA clusters themselves, adding support to a model of antagonistic co-evolution between TEs and the piRNA pathway.

To be completed in 2015, this dissertation work is an important contribution to the science, and in particular, to the study of evolution of TEs. TEs contribute ~ 50% of the human genome and TE misregulation in humans have been linked to several diseases, including cancer. Understanding host/TE dynamics using fruit fly as a model organism would help extrapolate our understandings to treat human diseases. Furthermore, Vedanayagam developed a bioinformatics course and taught for high-school students during Summer 2013 as part of the Rochester Scholars Program at the University of Rochester. This course work titled 'Genes and genomes: why is DNA the secret molecule of life?' provided hands-on training on bioinformatics for 15 high school students. Upon publication, the sequence data generated from this study will be made publicly available through the National Center for Biotechnology Information.
